meta.description: Thinking about what it means for an inÂ­dusÂ­try to deÂ­terÂ­mine a morale stanÂ­dard of pracÂ­tice.

content:
Since the beÂ­ginÂ­ning of this sumÂ­mer, with everyÂ­thing thatâ€™s deÂ­scendÂ­ing upon us with Covid-19 and the Black Lives Matter upÂ­risÂ­ing, it feels like we are livÂ­ing through a moÂ­ment of moral acÂ­countÂ­ing. In Portland, anÂ­tifa is in the street in runÂ­ning batÂ­tles with seÂ­cret poÂ­lice, exÂ­ploited workÂ­ers are speakÂ­ing up about the reÂ­alÂ­iÂ­ties of our treaÂ­sured restauÂ­rant inÂ­dusÂ­try, busiÂ­ness ownÂ­ers are shutÂ­ting down and pulling a disÂ­apÂ­pearÂ­ing act inÂ­stead of facÂ­ing acÂ­countÂ­abilÂ­ity for their beÂ­havÂ­ior. This has me thinkÂ­ing about my inÂ­dusÂ­try, which we all know has masÂ­sive probÂ­lems around racism, techno-fasÂ­cism, and robÂ­ber-baron level exÂ­ploitaÂ­tion. Weâ€™re still dealÂ­ing with peoÂ­ple who read Snow Crash and Neuromancer and think those books were deÂ­scripÂ­tions of Utopias.

There are a lot of peoÂ­ple doÂ­ing hard work right now to adÂ­dress these isÂ­sues in the inÂ­dusÂ­try, workÂ­ing to idenÂ­tify how we can â€” as busiÂ­nesses â€” move toÂ­ward a more just sysÂ­tem of workÂ­ing, how we need to avoid bakÂ­ing our prejÂ­uÂ­dices in to the AIs we build, and how the physÂ­iÂ­cal unÂ­derÂ­pinÂ­ning of the inÂ­terÂ­net is built on an exÂ­ploitaÂ­tive and exÂ­tracÂ­tive logic of global capÂ­iÂ­tal. This is all good and necÂ­esÂ­sary work. It makes me think though, about if there are disÂ­tincÂ­tions beÂ­tween the craft and pracÂ­tice of web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment and the busiÂ­ness logic and drive the inÂ­dusÂ­try. The inÂ­dusÂ­try vs the pracÂ­tice - as in the techÂ­niÂ­cal skill of paintÂ­ing vs the ecoÂ­nomic sysÂ­tem of paÂ­tronÂ­age. Clearly they are reÂ­lated, and clearly our conÂ­cepÂ­tion of paintÂ­ing has alÂ­ways been tied to the ecoÂ­nomic strucÂ­tures that make it a reÂ­alÂ­ity as a proÂ­fesÂ­sion, but is there a way to think about an Ethical Web Development? It would be tied to runÂ­ning an ethÂ­iÂ­cal busiÂ­ness, and necÂ­esÂ­sarÂ­ily need to be supÂ­portÂ­ing by an ethÂ­iÂ­cal ecoÂ­nomic sysÂ­tem, but how could we arÂ­ticÂ­uÂ­late what it would look like the perÂ­form the craft and pracÂ­tice of web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment ethÂ­iÂ­cally? What would an anÂ­tiracist and anÂ­tifasÂ­cist web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment pracÂ­tice look like?s

Recently we were visÂ­itÂ­ing my parÂ­ents in Corvallis, and as it hapÂ­pens my moms partÂ­ner is Michal Nelson - a moral philosoÂ­pher who speÂ­cialÂ­izes in ecoÂ­logÂ­iÂ­cal and enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­menÂ­tal ethics. So I asked him if there were any frameÂ­works for deÂ­terÂ­minÂ­ing if a given inÂ­dusÂ­try (his disÂ­ciÂ­pline foÂ­cuses on forestry and reÂ­source manÂ­ageÂ­ment for exÂ­amÂ­ple) was actÂ­ing â€œethicallyâ€. How does an inÂ­dusÂ­try set its own stanÂ­dard of ethÂ­iÂ­cal beÂ­havÂ­ior? He exÂ­plained that actÂ­ing â€œethicallyâ€ is esÂ­senÂ­tially just stayÂ­ing inÂ­terÂ­nally conÂ­sisÂ­tent to a set of valÂ­ues that youâ€™ve arÂ­ticÂ­uÂ­lated â€” and in this way beÂ­ing â€œethicalâ€ or â€œsustainableâ€ doesÂ­nâ€™t inÂ­herÂ­ently hold any value. Many peoÂ­ple or enÂ­tiÂ­ties agree on the imÂ­porÂ­tance of actÂ­ing ethÂ­iÂ­cally, but their baseÂ­line for what the core conÂ­cepts acÂ­tuÂ­ally mean, what they are talkÂ­ing about when they mean â€œharmâ€ for exÂ­amÂ­ple can vary wildly.

An ethÂ­iÂ­cal frameÂ­work is a tool to reÂ­duce the posÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity space - to help deÂ­terÂ­mine what choices availÂ­able should be taken rather than could be taken. It creÂ­ates a heurisÂ­tic for deÂ­terÂ­minÂ­ing which acÂ­tions will culÂ­tiÂ­vate an enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment that supÂ­ports a set of deÂ­sired valÂ­ues. Determining ethÂ­iÂ­cal conÂ­sidÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tions beÂ­comes a deÂ­sign probÂ­lem â€” what valÂ­ues do we want to see in the world? What outÂ­comes do we want and why? Who are we conÂ­sidÂ­erÂ­ing, who are we not conÂ­sidÂ­erÂ­ing? What are the edges and the limÂ­iÂ­taÂ­tions beÂ­yond which we deÂ­cide not to conÂ­cern ourÂ­selves?

There are many ethics availÂ­able to work from, and conÂ­ï¬‚atÂ­ing a sinÂ­gle ethic with the enÂ­tire range of posÂ­siÂ­ble ethics can be a probÂ­lem. If we asÂ­sume that a utilÂ­iÂ­tarÂ­ian, inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­uÂ­alÂ­ist ethic is the only posÂ­siÂ­ble ethic we can work with (cough cough ecoÂ­nomÂ­ics cough cough) it will necÂ­esÂ­sarÂ­ily preÂ­clude a whole range of outÂ­comes that just arenâ€™t posÂ­siÂ­ble to arÂ­rive at from those startÂ­ing conÂ­diÂ­tions. Another ethic based on comÂ­pasÂ­sion, anÂ­iÂ­mism, and colÂ­lecÂ­tivism would start with wildly difÂ­ferÂ­ent axÂ­ioms and natÂ­uÂ­rally arÂ­rive at difÂ­ferÂ­ent outÂ­comes. This deÂ­bate and tenÂ­sion is at play toÂ­day among the peoÂ­ple who study and try and outÂ­line what a susÂ­tainÂ­able fuÂ­ture of forÂ­est manÂ­ageÂ­ment is - itâ€™s an onÂ­goÂ­ing conÂ­verÂ­saÂ­tion (argument?) beÂ­tween peoÂ­ple who donâ€™t share the same baÂ­sic axÂ­ioms around what they are tryÂ­ing to talk about.

Perhaps the core of any ethic is â€œharm reÂ­ducÂ­tionâ€. We can see this in the Hippocratic oath and the medÂ­ical ethic â€” ï¬rst do no harm. The isÂ­sue is that â€œharmâ€ is not a natÂ­ural, disÂ­covÂ­erÂ­able propÂ­erty of the natÂ­ural world. Harm is necÂ­esÂ­sarÂ­ily framed as a value judgÂ­ment, the corolÂ­lary to the idea of â€œgood in the exÂ­panded ï¬eldâ€. We can outÂ­line the strucÂ­tural reÂ­quireÂ­ments and deÂ­fÂ­iÂ­nÂ­iÂ­tions of harm, and use those value judgÂ­ments to idenÂ­tify harm in the world, but itâ€™s still a huÂ­man judgeÂ­ment sysÂ­tem beÂ­ing used to sort and orÂ­der the world. The medÂ­ical world to ilÂ­lusÂ­trate this, we can look at the conÂ­temÂ­poÂ­rary preÂ­rogÂ­aÂ­tive of â€œinformed conÂ­sentâ€. We now deÂ­ï¬ne lack agency over medÂ­ical deÂ­ciÂ­sions as a harm done to an inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual. This has not alÂ­ways been the case.

This starts to get at the ecoÂ­logÂ­iÂ­cal conÂ­necÂ­tions beÂ­tween the craft and the busiÂ­ness and web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment - we can easÂ­ily frame acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity as a funÂ­daÂ­menÂ­tal reÂ­quireÂ­ment of an ethÂ­iÂ­cal web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment pracÂ­tice in that it reÂ­duces the harm of exÂ­cludÂ­ing inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­uÂ­als from our work. But we can arÂ­rive at that prinÂ­ciÂ­ple from the logic of many difÂ­ferÂ­ent ethics, some of which could be wildly conÂ­traÂ­dicÂ­tory. From a utilÂ­iÂ­tarÂ­ian, efÂ­ï¬Â­ciency and proï¬t maxÂ­iÂ­mizÂ­ing ethic, creÂ­atÂ­ing acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­ble web apps is ethÂ­iÂ­cal beÂ­cause not doÂ­ing so would be to leave money on the table. From a huÂ­manÂ­isÂ­tic and comÂ­pasÂ­sionÂ­ate ethic, itâ€™s acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­ble beÂ­cause it fosÂ­ters inÂ­cluÂ­sion and eqÂ­uity. So we see acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity and a clearly deÂ­ï¬ned ethÂ­iÂ­cal pracÂ­tice, but that doesÂ­nâ€™t mean that we all agree on why acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity is ethÂ­iÂ­cal.

I think in orÂ­der for us to deÂ­ï¬ne what we mean when we try and deÂ­ï¬ne how our inÂ­dusÂ­try can be ethÂ­iÂ­cal, we need to work through a few steps:

  1. What valÂ­ues do we want to enÂ­courÂ­age and fosÂ­ter in the enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment?
  2. Where do we draw the disÂ­tincÂ­tion beÂ­tween things we are conÂ­cerned with and things we are not?
  3. How do we deÂ­terÂ­mine who is efÂ­fected by our ethic and who is not?
  4. How do we then deÂ­ï¬ne the rules for deÂ­terÂ­mine which acÂ­tions we should take and which acÂ­tions we should not take?

If, as an inÂ­dusÂ­try and as inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­uÂ­als, we can have these conÂ­verÂ­saÂ­tions then we can start to come to terms with what it means to work every day in a world where we are acÂ­tively supÂ­portÂ­ing and enÂ­richÂ­ing the worlds ï¬rst trilÂ­lionÂ­aire. Is an ethÂ­iÂ­cal web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment one where we must boyÂ­cott AWS? How do we feel about data cenÂ­ters in genÂ­eral? What about ISPs, what about unÂ­derÂ­waÂ­ter caÂ­bles?

Jaya Saxenaâ€™s reÂ­cent piece in Eater clearly idenÂ­tiÂ­ï¬es the probÂ­lems asÂ­soÂ­ciÂ­ated with actÂ­ing ethÂ­iÂ­cally as an inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual â€” or even an inÂ­dusÂ­try â€” while reÂ­mainÂ­ing a part of a soÂ­ciÂ­ety that sysÂ­temÂ­iÂ­cally unÂ­derÂ­mines that ethic through strucÂ­tural deÂ­sign.

Building an eqÂ­uiÂ­table restauÂ­rant, a place where all workÂ­ers are paid fairly, have benÂ­eÂ­ï¬ts, and can work in an anti-disÂ­crimÂ­iÂ­naÂ­tory enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment, is goÂ­ing to take a near-unÂ­doÂ­ing of the way most restauÂ­rants are run.

Saxena exÂ­amÂ­ines some curÂ­rent modÂ­els for emÂ­ployee-owned and coÂ­opÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tive busiÂ­nesses, and priÂ­vately owned busiÂ­ness that acÂ­tively choose equalÂ­ity and comÂ­muÂ­nity over proï¬t. She idenÂ­tiÂ­ï¬es that is a comÂ­proÂ­mise in these enÂ­terÂ­prises, and sums up the sysÂ­tem isÂ­sues at hand by conÂ­cussing that â€œâ€¦ when it comes to restauÂ­rants, itâ€™s hard to change one thing unÂ­less youâ€™re changÂ­ing everyÂ­thing.â€

There are sysÂ­temic forces at work that preÂ­vent any inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual, or even any small comÂ­muÂ­nity from truly reachÂ­ing a place of ethÂ­iÂ­cal beÂ­havÂ­ior. This makes me think that there has to be a split beÂ­tween â€œacting ethÂ­iÂ­callyâ€ and â€œbeing ethÂ­iÂ­calâ€. We can all act ethÂ­iÂ­cally, workÂ­ing our way upÂ­stream against the sysÂ­tem forces arÂ­rayed against us, but thatâ€™s no guarÂ­anÂ­tee that we will, at the end of the day, be ethÂ­iÂ­cal.

The esÂ­say idenÂ­tiÂ­ï¬es one restauÂ­rant and farm that solves their ethÂ­iÂ­cal criÂ­sis by charÂ­ing $195 per perÂ­son per meal, and frames that as a choice that conÂ­sumers get to make. This is strikÂ­ing. We live in a time of unÂ­preceÂ­dented efÂ­ï¬Â­ciency, unÂ­beÂ­lievÂ­able abunÂ­dance, and masÂ­sive wealth but if a restauÂ­rant is called to truly acÂ­count for its exÂ­ploitaÂ­tion to charge its true price, itâ€™s imÂ­meÂ­diÂ­ately unÂ­tenÂ­able. This feels like it must be true across many inÂ­dusÂ­tries — Uber would rather cease serÂ­vice in California than treat itâ€™s driÂ­vers like emÂ­ployÂ­ees. What would it take to truly unÂ­derÂ­stand what the netÂ­work of costs, valÂ­ues, debts, and the real price of things?

Would an ethÂ­iÂ­cal web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment be able to acÂ­count for that cost and still be able to be a busiÂ­ness in our soÂ­ciÂ­ety? During my early courses in ï¬ne art printÂ­makÂ­ing at University, I was taught that a blank sheet of paÂ­per had value on its own. Not only the price atÂ­tached to it (steep, for nice paÂ­per) but also the work and craft that went in to makÂ­ing it. One had to be sure that the imÂ­age we weâ€™re imÂ­pressÂ­ing on the blank sheet of paÂ­per added value to it that than reÂ­duced it. Our work had to be more valuÂ­able than the paÂ­per, and if it wasÂ­nâ€™t we didÂ­nâ€™t make it.

Ingrid Burrington has writÂ­ten exÂ­tenÂ­sively about the physÂ­iÂ­cal reÂ­alÂ­iÂ­ties of the inÂ­terÂ­net, and what it means to turn the raw stuff of the earth into the obÂ­jects we need to make comÂ­putÂ­ers. Sheâ€™s even turned comÂ­putÂ­ers back into raw stuff. Itâ€™s hard to conÂ­front the reÂ­alÂ­ity of an open pit lithium mine and conÂ­clude that needs must for betÂ­ter batÂ­terÂ­ies.

Can web deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment be ethÂ­iÂ­cal? Maybe not. But that doesÂ­nâ€™t mean that we donâ€™t have an obligÂ­aÂ­tion to act ethÂ­iÂ­cally. If we can arÂ­ticÂ­uÂ­late the ethic we want to have in our inÂ­dusÂ­try, and stay inÂ­terÂ­nally conÂ­sisÂ­tent to those prinÂ­ciÂ­ples in an efÂ­fort to manÂ­iÂ­fest valÂ­ues we want in the world, maybe thatâ€™s enough. Or a start anyÂ­way.

content:
Working with Adam Riemer on SmugMugâ€™s SEO has been a reÂ­ally ilÂ­luÂ­miÂ­natÂ­ing exÂ­peÂ­riÂ­ence. SEO conÂ­sultÂ­ing has alÂ­ways been ï¬‚agged in my mind as â€œSnake Oil Businessâ€, but Adam reÂ­ally is the best in the ï¬eld. Almost all of his SEO sugÂ­gesÂ­tions foÂ­cus on perÂ­forÂ­mance and acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity, and he has some clear, hard metÂ­rics to deÂ­ï¬ne â€œgoodâ€. This squares with my funÂ­daÂ­menÂ­tal unÂ­derÂ­standÂ­ing of good SEO pracÂ­tices, and has broadÂ­ened my horiÂ­zons and unÂ­derÂ­standÂ­ing of of the pracÂ­tice.

Something that Adam inÂ­troÂ­duced me to is JSON-LD — a way of creÂ­atÂ­ing strucÂ­tured metaÂ­data for pages thatâ€™s more exÂ­plicit that miÂ­croÂ­data forÂ­mats. Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned about JSON-LD so far.

JSON-LD is Googleâ€™s preÂ­ferred forÂ­mat for acÂ­cuÂ­rately and sucÂ­cinctly strucÂ­turÂ­ing metaÂ­data for pages. This gives them inÂ­sight into whatâ€™s on your page and why, and they use The Algorithm to inÂ­terÂ­act and conÂ­sume this data. Using their stanÂ­dards gives you the opÂ­porÂ­tuÂ­nity to get top, fancy search reÂ­sults but thereâ€™s no guarÂ­anÂ­tee of that. The best thing to do is to use your strucÂ­tured data to give the best, more acÂ­cuÂ­rate, and comÂ­plete picÂ­ture of what conÂ­tent your page has for your auÂ­diÂ­ence. Trying to game SEO here is probÂ­aÂ­bly goÂ­ing to backÂ­ï¬re, just deÂ­scribe things as they are as clearly as posÂ­siÂ­ble.

The priÂ­mary purÂ­pose of strucÂ­tured data is to creÂ­ate a maÂ­chine-readÂ­able and alÂ­goÂ­rithm friendly metaÂ­data for your conÂ­tent. This alÂ­lows the conÂ­tent to be conÂ­sumed by the crawlers and the roÂ­bots, and join in the mesh of conÂ­tent that Google exÂ­poses to users when they perÂ­form searches or ask quesÂ­tions of it.

Clearly this is a douÂ­ble-edged propoÂ­siÂ­tion. By usÂ­ing strucÂ­tured data youâ€™re exÂ­plicÂ­itly buyÂ­ing in to the ecosysÂ­tem that Google is creÂ­atÂ­ing, and alÂ­lowÂ­ing your conÂ­tent to be trawled and used and unÂ­derÂ­stood howÂ­ever they want. You unÂ­doubtable end up proÂ­vidÂ­ing value to Google in exÂ­cess to what they are proÂ­vidÂ­ing to you. Not to menÂ­tion parÂ­ticÂ­iÂ­patÂ­ing in the proÂ­ject of makÂ­ing the world maÂ­chine-readÂ­able, which has itâ€™s own philoÂ­sophÂ­iÂ­cal freight.

Schema.org has a lot of data types that might be apÂ­proÂ­priÂ­ate for your proÂ­ject: Articles, Books, Breadcrumbs, Carousel, Course, Critic Review, Dataset, Event, How-to, Local Business, Movie, Podcast, Product, Software App, and Video are all ones that look inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing to me.

For someÂ­thing like this site, weâ€™re usÂ­ing pretty much enÂ­tirely Website and Article — and conÂ­nect them with a CollectionPage and a Person who is me! Maybe some of the art will be a CreativeWork.

Some inÂ­forÂ­maÂ­tion on these types:

  • Article: https://â€‹schema.org/â€‹ArÂ­tiÂ­cle
  • Person: https://â€‹schema.org/â€‹PerÂ­son
  • Collection Page: https://â€‹schema.org/â€‹ColÂ­lecÂ­tionÂ­Page
  • Creative Work: https://â€‹schema.org/â€‹CreÂ­ativeÂ­Work
  • Web Site: https://â€‹schema.org/â€‹WebÂ­Site

Lets work through Googleâ€™s exÂ­amÂ­ple of an arÂ­tiÂ­cle, maybe for this arÂ­tiÂ­cle!

Hereâ€™s the script tag that is home to our strucÂ­tured data:

<script type="application/ld+json">
â€¦
</script>

We ï¬ll it with a JSON obÂ­ject that deÂ­scribes our data strucÂ­ture:

{
  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "Article",
  "headline": "Article headline",
  "datePublished": "2020-08-25T16:42:53.786Z",
  "dateModified": "2020-08-25T16:42:53.786Z"
}

The @context key clues the roÂ­bot in to the data deÂ­fÂ­iÂ­nÂ­iÂ­tion weâ€™re goÂ­ing to be usÂ­ing, which is the schema.org deÂ­fÂ­iÂ­nÂ­iÂ­tions. The @type tag asÂ­soÂ­ciÂ­ates the folÂ­lowÂ­ing data with the pre-deÂ­ï¬ned strucÂ­ture. From there on itâ€™s relÂ­eÂ­vant data! headline, datePublished and dateModified are all diÂ­rectly pulled from the conÂ­tent itÂ­self. In out case our data looks like this:

{
  "@context": "https://schema.org",
  "@type": "Article",
  "headline": "Fun With JSON-LD",
  "datePublished": "2020-08-12T08:00:00+08:00",
  "dateModified": "2020-08-12T08:00:00+08:00"
}

Open quesÂ­tion: BlogPosting or Article? Im goÂ­ing to stick with BlogPosting since these texts are reÂ­ally just that. I would use Article if I was writÂ­ing a news piece or a reÂ­view, or someÂ­thing maybe more scholÂ­arly.

The last reÂ­quired ï¬eld is an image:

For best reÂ­sults, proÂ­vide mulÂ­tiÂ­ple high-resÂ­oÂ­luÂ­tion imÂ­ages (minimum of 300,000 pixÂ­els when mulÂ­tiÂ­plyÂ­ing width and height) with the folÂ­lowÂ­ing asÂ­pect raÂ­tios: 16x9, 4x3, and 1x1.

{
	â€¦
  "image": [
    "https://example.com/photos/1x1/photo.jpg",
    "https://example.com/photos/4x3/photo.jpg",
    "https://example.com/photos/16x9/photo.jpg"
  ]
}

This means that creÂ­atÂ­ing thumbÂ­nails for every Article is imÂ­porÂ­tant, and those imÂ­ages need to exÂ­ist on the page in a way that user can see.

For this site, the main use of these imÂ­ages is goÂ­ing to be for sharÂ­ing thumbÂ­nails. The fact that the imÂ­age needs to be on the pages is inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing, since that reÂ­ally inÂ­ï¬‚uÂ­ences the deÂ­sign of the page. Iâ€™ve found that creÂ­atÂ­ing the neÂ­cesÂ­sity for a promiÂ­nent thumbÂ­nail or hero imÂ­age that acÂ­comÂ­paÂ­nies each arÂ­tiÂ­cle is a recipe for a) not writÂ­ing arÂ­tiÂ­cles and b) bland stock phoÂ­togÂ­raÂ­phy. I want to avoid both. That means for this site Iâ€™m goÂ­ing to do ilÂ­lusÂ­trated imÂ­ages, small sketches and moÂ­tif exÂ­ploÂ­rations that may or may not ilÂ­lusÂ­trate the arÂ­tiÂ­cle, and atÂ­tach it to the botÂ­tom of the arÂ­tiÂ­cle.

There are two other secÂ­tions I want to look at, even though they are not reÂ­quireÂ­ments acÂ­cordÂ­ing to Google. These are the author and the publisher ï¬elds. The goal of usÂ­ing these ï¬elds is to creÂ­ate an asÂ­soÂ­ciÂ­aÂ­tion beÂ­tween you and your work; or in the case of the publisher ï¬eld beÂ­tween an imÂ­print enÂ­tity and the creÂ­ative works theyâ€™ve pubÂ­lished. In our use case for this site, my goal is to creÂ­ate a maÂ­chine-readÂ­able enÂ­tity that is â€˜Nikolas Wiseâ€™ and atÂ­tach my arÂ­tiÂ­cles and my work to that, in orÂ­der to creÂ­ate a coÂ­herÂ­ent enÂ­tity that is exÂ­posed to the broader web.

The author ï¬eld is a Person or an Organization, the publisher ï¬eld is an Organization. Lets start with Person:

A perÂ­son (alive, dead, unÂ­dead, or ï¬cÂ­tional). https://â€‹schema.org/â€‹PerÂ­son

It gets added to our LSON-LD like this:

{
	â€¦
  "author": {
	  "@type": "Person",
	  â€¦
  }
}

There are a lot of propÂ­erÂ­ties in this schema, like deathPlace and knows. One could reÂ­ally get into this and make it a very roÂ­bust and comÂ­plete data obÂ­ject, but Iâ€™m not sure how much value that would bring at the end of the day. Thereâ€™s a ï¬ne line beÂ­tween folÂ­lowÂ­ing specs and best pracÂ­tices to achieve a goal and tickÂ­ing boxes to strucÂ­ture our lives solely in orÂ­der to make them legÂ­iÂ­ble to the alÂ­goÂ­rithm. I guess we each deÂ­cide where that line is for ourÂ­selves.

For me, Iâ€™m goÂ­ing to stick with name, url, image, jobTitle, knowsLanguage, and sameAs. Although publishingPrinciples seems inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing, and I might write one of those.

Most of the ï¬elds are simÂ­ple text strings, and can get ï¬lled out like so:

{
	â€¦
  "author": {
	  "@type": "Person",
		"name": "Nikolas Wise",
		"url": "https://nikolas.ws",
		"image": "https://photos.smugmug.com/Portraits/i-ThnJCF5/0/f9013fdc/X4/wise-X4.jpg",
		"jobTitle": "Web Developer",
		"knowsLanguage": "en, fr",
		"sameAs": â€¦,
  }
}

The lanÂ­guage codes are from the lanÂ­guage code spec, and could also be lanÂ­guage schema obÂ­jects. The job tiÂ­tle could be a Deï¬ned Term schema obÂ­ject.

The sameAs key is an inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing one, itâ€™s eiÂ­ther a URL or an arÂ­ray of URLs that conÂ­nect this @person with other parts of the web that are also that @person.

{
	â€¦
  "@person": {
	  â€¦
		"sameAs": [
			"https://twitter.com/nikolaswise",
			"https://github.com/nikolaswise",
			"https://www.instagram.com/nikolaswise/",
			"https://www.linkedin.com/in/nikolas-wise-6b170265/",
		],
  }
}

This will conÂ­nect â€œmeâ€ with this site and my twitÂ­ter, github, inÂ­staÂ­gram, and linkedin proÂ­ï¬les. Those are the pages that I want to the alÂ­goÂ­rithm to asÂ­soÂ­ciÂ­ate with â€œmeâ€.

@organization is simÂ­iÂ­lar to @person in a lot of ways, and the funÂ­daÂ­menÂ­tal idea is the same. content:
TL:DR; Start here. Install this thing and conÂ­nect it to your acÂ­count on here. Buy a liÂ­cense of this (itâ€™s worth it). Read some docs for this and start buildÂ­ing. Wordpress 5 and Gutenberg will probÂ­aÂ­bly break all of this exÂ­cept the enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ments.

When I ï¬rst started workÂ­ing as a deÂ­velÂ­oper, Wordpress was the prevaÂ­lent platÂ­form for pretty much any proÂ­ject. Ten years later and â€¦ Wordpress is still pretty much most of the inÂ­terÂ­net. In genÂ­eral, Wordpress will be my last choice of a platÂ­form. I preÂ­fer to build staÂ­tic sites, use a headÂ­less CMS, or alÂ­most anyÂ­thing else at all.

That said, as the Technical Director at Fuzzco â€” a deÂ­sign stuÂ­dio that reÂ­lies alÂ­most exÂ­cluÂ­sively on Wordpress for their webÂ­sites â€” Wordpress was hapÂ­penÂ­ing. Fuzzco is rare among stuÂ­dios in that we manÂ­age and host proÂ­jects for our clients, and ofÂ­ten have mainÂ­teÂ­nance ridÂ­ers that can last for years. This means that in the course of a year, not only did we build a half dozen new proÂ­jects on Wordpress, but we mainÂ­tained and triaged isÂ­sues on over 100 legacy proÂ­jects.

Very quickly I reÂ­alÂ­ized I had one opÂ­tion: make Wordpress not terÂ­riÂ­ble.

Terrible is pretty harsh

If youâ€™re comÂ­fortÂ­able with Wordpress, you might ï¬nd some ï¬ghtÂ­inâ€™ words here. Whatâ€™s my probÂ­lem with Wordpress and what am I tryÂ­ing to solve for? My biggest isÂ­sue with Wordpress deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment as Iâ€™ve enÂ­counÂ­tered it in the past is a lack of clarÂ­ity around the reÂ­quireÂ­ments of the enÂ­tire sysÂ­tem. What does the proÂ­ject need to run in an enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment, and why? How do we move from a reposÂ­iÂ­tory to a loÂ­cal enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment and start workÂ­ing on a codeÂ­base? How does that codeÂ­base get deÂ­ployed to a server?

Iâ€™ve seen Wordpress sysÂ­tems that are frozen in time in 2006 â€” FTP to the server and edit a CSS ï¬le on proÂ­ducÂ­tion, or â€œdeployâ€ your theme by upÂ­loadÂ­ing a .zip. Iâ€™m inÂ­terÂ­ested in how we can lower the cogÂ­niÂ­tive overÂ­head for getÂ­ting a Wordpress proÂ­ject up and runÂ­ning, and join in with pre-proÂ­cessÂ­ing, comÂ­pilÂ­ing, conÂ­tainerÂ­izÂ­ing, testÂ­ing, and all the reÂ­ally exÂ­celÂ­lent things that weâ€™ve come to exÂ­pect from our web stacks over the past few years.

Another isÂ­sue I have with Wordpress is its comÂ­mitÂ­ment to auto-magÂ­iÂ­cal routes and renÂ­derÂ­ing temÂ­plates with obÂ­scure and comÂ­pliÂ­cated .php patÂ­terns that baÂ­siÂ­cally conÂ­cateÂ­nate strings. Iâ€™m inÂ­terÂ­ested in exÂ­plicit routes â€” eiÂ­ther hard-coded or paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­terÂ­ized â€” and sepÂ­aÂ­ratÂ­ing conÂ­cerns beÂ­tween logic and temÂ­plate.

A lot of this boils down to a disÂ­agreeÂ­ment beÂ­tween what Wordpress thinks a site should be and what I end up usÂ­ing it for. Wordpress as deÂ­signed disÂ­tinÂ­guishes beÂ­tween your â€œsiteâ€ and your â€œthemeâ€. Your â€œsiteâ€ is the conÂ­tent in the dataÂ­base, the opÂ­tions youâ€™ve saved, and the menus and widÂ­gets youâ€™ve inÂ­stalled. It exÂ­pects â€œthemesâ€ to be preÂ­senÂ­taÂ­tions of this real webÂ­site stuff. This model of webÂ­sites perÂ­petÂ­uÂ­ates that â€œdesignâ€ is someÂ­thing that can be apÂ­plied over a webÂ­site, a kind of dressÂ­ing up of the real things. This is the inÂ­verse, and perÂ­haps a corolÂ­lary to, the conÂ­cept that deÂ­signÂ­ing a webÂ­site is just deÂ­cidÂ­ing what it looks like. Itâ€™s an idea that lives within the sysÂ­tem of siÂ­los beÂ­tween deÂ­sign and deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment, and that we can â€œdesignâ€ a webÂ­site in Photoshop or Sketch and hand off the comps to a deÂ­velÂ­oper to build it. Which is how a lot of Wordpress proÂ­jects are built.

In short, I disÂ­agree with this conÂ­cept of webÂ­sites. My poÂ­siÂ­tion is that deÂ­signÂ­ing a webÂ­site is both how it looks, how it works, and how the data and strucÂ­tures are comÂ­posed. Taking this apÂ­proach, conÂ­trolÂ­ling the obÂ­ject modÂ­els, the inÂ­forÂ­maÂ­tion arÂ­chiÂ­tecÂ­tures, and the temÂ­plates are all of equal imÂ­porÂ­tance. In my line of work, a Wordpress theme can not be apÂ­plied to any other site than the one that it was deÂ­signed for, a site where the strucÂ­ture was deÂ­signed for the theme.

So why use Wordpress?

There are still a numÂ­ber of reÂ­ally good, comÂ­pelling reaÂ­sons to use Wordpress as a platÂ­form for buildÂ­ing webÂ­sites. Itâ€™s got a roÂ­bust built-in comÂ­mentÂ­ing sysÂ­tem with user acÂ­counts. Itâ€™s reÂ­ally good for things that are shaped like blogs. Itâ€™s got a huge, well-mainÂ­tained ecosysÂ­tem of pluÂ­gÂ­ins. Itâ€™s free. And since itâ€™s most of the Internet, clients are reÂ­ally, reÂ­ally comÂ­fortÂ­able with it.

There are a couÂ­ple of reaÂ­sons not to use Wordpress right now. Mostly these cenÂ­ter around the imÂ­pendÂ­ing reÂ­lease of Wordpress 5.0 and the Gutenberg edÂ­iÂ­tor, which has a numÂ­ber of conÂ­cerns around pluÂ­gin comÂ­patÂ­iÂ­bilÂ­ity and acÂ­cesÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity for auÂ­thors.

But thatâ€™s okay, since weâ€™ve deÂ­cided to use Wordpress 4.x. As we all know, pickÂ­ing a verÂ­sion of Wordpress and then never upÂ­gradÂ­ing it is one of the time honÂ­ored traÂ­diÂ­tions of Wordpress deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment.

How does this work even

Letâ€™s start at the end.

Weâ€™re goÂ­ing to be hostÂ­ing our proÂ­ducÂ­tion Wordpress site on a Digital Ocean droplet â€” the smallÂ­est one they have â€” for $5 per month. Depending on the proÂ­ject lifeÂ­cyÂ­cle, we can set up more droplets for a stagÂ­ing server and a deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment server. At Fuzzco we used dev servers to show sites to the inÂ­terÂ­nal team, stagÂ­ing servers to show sites to the client, and proÂ­ducÂ­tion servers to show sites to the pubÂ­lic.

I donâ€™t know about you, but I perÂ­sonÂ­ally donâ€™t suÂ­per love manÂ­agÂ­ing my virÂ­tual priÂ­vate servers manÂ­uÂ­ally. In orÂ­der to deÂ­ploy our codeÂ­bases to Digital Ocean weâ€™ll use the pheÂ­nomÂ­eÂ­nal tool Nanobox. Nanobox is an opÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tions layer that hanÂ­dles conÂ­tainerÂ­izÂ­ing apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tions and deÂ­ployÂ­ing them agÂ­nosÂ­tiÂ­cally to a cloud serÂ­vice provider. Nanobox will deÂ­ploy our code from the comÂ­mand line to any one of our droplets.

Nanobox will also conÂ­tainerÂ­ize and run an apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion in a virÂ­tual maÂ­chine loÂ­cally. This means weâ€™ll use it to run our deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment, and enÂ­sure that all of our enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ments are idenÂ­tiÂ­cal. No more worÂ­ryÂ­ing about PHP verÂ­sions and exÂ­tenÂ­sions and pluÂ­gÂ­ins. No more runÂ­ning MAMP or MySQL or Apache or whatÂ­ever on your loÂ­cal maÂ­chine beÂ­fore anyÂ­thing works. Nanobox deÂ­ï¬nes the server in a .yaml ï¬le, and it will alÂ­ways be the same. It also hanÂ­dles all the syncÂ­ing beÂ­tween our loÂ­cal disk and our virÂ­tual enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ment.

So now that we know how our code is goÂ­ing from loÂ­cal to proÂ­ducÂ­tion, we can think for a secÂ­ond about how itâ€™s goÂ­ing to do that, and how weâ€™re goÂ­ing to manÂ­age our data.

The dataÂ­base on the proÂ­ducÂ­tion server is â€œcanonicalâ€. That means that the dataÂ­base the client inÂ­terÂ­acts with is the one true dataÂ­base, and we must treat it with care and atÂ­tenÂ­tion. Weâ€™ll never change that dataÂ­base ourÂ­selves, and weâ€™ll move that dataÂ­base downÂ­stream from proÂ­ducÂ­tion to stagÂ­ing to dev to loÂ­cal in orÂ­der to deÂ­velop against our real data. Importantly, we donâ€™t want to miÂ­grate the dataÂ­base manÂ­uÂ­ally eiÂ­ther. Itâ€™s a litÂ­tle exÂ­penÂ­sive but usÂ­ing Migrate DB Pro is an inÂ­credÂ­iÂ­ble reÂ­source for this part. I guess one could also look into alÂ­terÂ­naÂ­tives for perÂ­sonal proÂ­jects.

The canonÂ­iÂ­cal codeÂ­base lives in verÂ­sion conÂ­trol, and moves the other diÂ­recÂ­tion. From Github to loÂ­cal to dev to stagÂ­ing to proÂ­ducÂ­tion, amen. The only things we need to track in verÂ­sion conÂ­trol are what makes our proÂ­ject unique. Practically, this means we need to track our theme and our pluÂ­gÂ­ins. Wordpress core ï¬les are not speÂ­cial, and we should not ï¬ll our reposÂ­iÂ­toÂ­ries with them.

Getting started

At this point itâ€™s worth getÂ­ting started with Nanobox. I back the conÂ­tainÂ­ers with VirtualBox, since at the time I started this it was slightly more staÂ­ble than Docker on MacOS High Sierra. Once Nanobox & Virtualbox/Docker is inÂ­stalled, set up Digital Ocean as your provider. Once thatâ€™s done, we have everyÂ­thing we need to get started!

Iâ€™ll be talkÂ­ing through a proÂ­ject I built in orÂ­der to faÂ­cilÂ­iÂ­tate buildÂ­ing other proÂ­jects. This will be more inÂ­tense than you might need for a sinÂ­gle build, but this was deÂ­signed a tool that anyÂ­one can use to get started quickly. Hereâ€™s the baÂ­sic strucÂ­ture of our repo:

Degit will only get the head ï¬les, and none of the git hisÂ­tory. Nor will it keep the .git ï¬le, baÂ­siÂ­cally makÂ­ing this a suÂ­per clean, suÂ­per fast way to downÂ­load a diÂ­recÂ­tory of ï¬les. Itâ€™s great. The last thing this does is wipe out any themes or pluÂ­gÂ­ins that we donâ€™t want our need in the core ï¬les and syncs out own tracked diÂ­recÂ­toÂ­ries to the corÂ­rect places in the Wordpress core ï¬le strucÂ­ture.

Now would be a time to talk about pluÂ­gÂ­ins.

Whatâ€™s up with pluÂ­gÂ­ins?

Wordpress has a milÂ­lion pluÂ­gÂ­ins. Weâ€™re goÂ­ing to foÂ­cus on some of the baÂ­sic ones that alÂ­most every Wordpress proÂ­ject ever needs, and should honÂ­estly be part of Wordpress. Building sites withÂ­out these is a pain. Here they are:

Advanced Custom Fields

ACF is a staÂ­ple of Wordpress deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment. It lets us deÂ­ï¬ne new key/â€‹value pairs to exÂ­tend the data model of things like posts and pages, and alÂ­lows us to creÂ­ate a set of global variÂ­able availÂ­able from anyÂ­where. Sounds simÂ­ple, surÂ­prisÂ­ing itâ€™s not part of Wordpress.

CPT-UI creÂ­ates an inÂ­terÂ­face in the adÂ­min panel for creÂ­atÂ­ing new post types. Out of the box, Wordpress comes with Posts and Pages. CPT-UI lets us build new types like Projects or Case Studies or whatÂ­ever need for our data model. Again, surÂ­prisÂ­ing that this isÂ­nâ€™t just part of Wordpress. Câ€™est la vivre.

Migrate DB lets us â€¦ miÂ­grate â€¦ our â€¦ DB. This gives us the abilÂ­ity to sync our dataÂ­bases across enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ments and get meÂ­dia upÂ­loads and things withÂ­out needÂ­ing to write magic MySQL queries while tunÂ­neled into open dataÂ­base ports on virÂ­tual maÂ­chines. Timber

The Timber liÂ­brary from Upstatement is the greatÂ­est thing to hapÂ­pen to Wordpress deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment, afÂ­ter those pluÂ­gÂ­ins that should just be part of Wordpress. Timber inÂ­troÂ­duces the conÂ­cept of layÂ­out temÂ­plates to Wordpress. This lets us write PHP to maÂ­nipÂ­uÂ­late data, and pass that data to a temÂ­plate ï¬le where we can write Twig temÂ­plates rather than comÂ­posÂ­ing strings in PHP. Basically â€¦

This lets us write temÂ­plates with a temÂ­platÂ­ing lanÂ­guage, and write server-side busiÂ­ness logic in a server-side proÂ­gramÂ­ming lanÂ­guage. Truly revÂ­oÂ­luÂ­tionÂ­ary.

What we talk about when we talk about Wordpress deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment: or, The Theme.

With all this iniÂ­tial work around Wordpress core, deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ments, and a baÂ­sic pluÂ­gin ecosysÂ­tem in place we can start talkÂ­ing about the good stuff: the theme!

Functions, Routes, and Views

The last thing I want to touch on is the baÂ­sic strucÂ­ture of usÂ­ing Timber to match routes with views.

  Timber::render( array(
    'views/pages/page-' . $post->post_name . '.twig',
    'views/pages/page.twig'
  ), $context );
?>

The page.php ï¬le asÂ­signs some variÂ­ables, inÂ­terÂ­acts with Wordpress to get and shape our data, and then renÂ­ders the twig ï¬le asÂ­soÂ­ciÂ­ated with the page. In this case, itâ€™s goÂ­ing to see if thereâ€™s a temÂ­plate that matches the name of our page, othÂ­erÂ­wise it will renÂ­der the deÂ­fault page temÂ­plate.

Back to the beÂ­ginÂ­ning

Youâ€™ve built your theme! Maybe itâ€™s a simÂ­ple hello world, maybe itâ€™s a heavy duty big olâ€™ thing. Either way, itâ€™s time to deÂ­ploy.

You can use Nanobox to creÂ­ate a droplet for your server. Nanobox will give your proÂ­ject a name in their sysÂ­tem, and exÂ­pose the URL for the server at <your-project>.nanoapp.io. I like to use the conÂ­venÂ­tion project-dev, project-stage, and project-prod. Once you creÂ­ate your proÂ­ject in Nanobox, the hard part is over and you can let them do the heavy liftÂ­ing:

$ nanobox deploy project-dev

Or we can map this to our NPM script:

$ npm run deploy:dev

This will conÂ­tainerÂ­ize our apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion, push it to our droplet, hyÂ­drate the enÂ­tire thing, and serve! Now we can use Migrate DB to move our dataÂ­base around, and weâ€™re in busiÂ­ness.

Putting it all toÂ­gether

The proÂ­ject repo is a turnkey, ready to roll verÂ­sion of all the above. It conÂ­tains all the toolÂ­ing needed to get started, and if youâ€™ve folÂ­lowed along with this guide, you should be able to get started in no time.

As alÂ­ways, feel free to reach out to me in your venue of choice to talk about any of this â€” I would be happy to help you set this up for your own Wordpress proÂ­ject!

meta.title: Soft Proof
meta.description: Translations and comÂ­proÂ­mises in imÂ­age makÂ­ing or; the Image Cult Society.

content:
Thereâ€™s an inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing thing that hapÂ­pens when a new idea or techÂ­nolÂ­ogy gets inÂ­troÂ­duced then quickly asÂ­simÂ­iÂ­lated into the backÂ­ground hum of our daily lives. It starts out with a disÂ­creet name â€” a clear idenÂ­tiÂ­ï¬er of what this thing is and means. Than this name just sort of â€¦ slips away. It beÂ­comes so norÂ­mal that to name it would seem strange. Its origÂ­iÂ­nal name doesÂ­nâ€™t seem to ï¬t any more, as the name exÂ­isted in the ï¬rst place to deÂ­marÂ­cate the new thought from the orÂ­diÂ­nary. And now the new thing is just orÂ­diÂ­nary. Think about Google Maps. Itâ€™s just â€¦ a map. In 2005, when Google Maps was ï¬rst reÂ­leased, itâ€™s parÂ­ticÂ­uÂ­lar apÂ­proach to the inÂ­terÂ­face of a digÂ­iÂ­tal map was called a â€˜slippy mapâ€™. Weird, right?

This is an inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing pheÂ­nomÂ­eÂ­non around culÂ­tural apÂ­proaches to techÂ­nolÂ­ogy, but not acÂ­tuÂ­ally what I want to talk about. I want to talk about soft proofs. Soft proofs are an exÂ­amÂ­ple of this taken to an exÂ­treme â€” you use them every day but you have probÂ­aÂ­bly never heard of them. There is no need for the soft proof to be someÂ­thing other than norÂ­mal, the soft proof just is norÂ­mal. But what is a soft proof, and why is it so norÂ­mal? And why do I want to exÂ­plore a topic so quoÂ­tidÂ­ian that the word used to mark it as inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing is so faded and worn?

A soft proof is a way of viewÂ­ing an imÂ­age beÂ­fore the imÂ­age has been reÂ­proÂ­duced meÂ­chanÂ­iÂ­cally. In conÂ­trast to the soft proof is the hard proof: a way of viewÂ­ing an imÂ­age imÂ­meÂ­diÂ­ately afÂ­ter itâ€™s been reÂ­proÂ­duced meÂ­chanÂ­iÂ­cally. Basically, a soft proof is an imÂ­age on a screen that will be sent to a printer. Otherwise known as an imÂ­age. Itâ€™s need for a disÂ­creet name seems so unÂ­necÂ­esÂ­sary that it seems bizarre to reÂ­fer to all imÂ­ages - even this text as I write it — as soft proofs. But that is, in essence, what they are. We see imÂ­ages on our screens that an be reÂ­liÂ­ably turned into imÂ­ages on other peoÂ­ples screens, and even into physÂ­iÂ­cal imÂ­ages on paÂ­per.

The reaÂ­son why this needed a name to deÂ­marÂ­cate it as speÂ­cial â€” durÂ­ing the adÂ­vent of the digÂ­iÂ­tal â€” is that this is a reÂ­ally hard probÂ­lem to solve. There are a range of mathÂ­eÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cal modÂ­els for apÂ­proachÂ­ing a relÂ­aÂ­tively uniÂ­ï¬ed theÂ­ory of color and viÂ­sion, and a wide range of physÂ­iÂ­cal pieces of maÂ­chinÂ­ery that are tasked with proÂ­ducÂ­ing those imÂ­ages â€” from printÂ­ing presses to monÂ­iÂ­tors. The act of enÂ­surÂ­ing an imÂ­age can be preÂ­dictably reÂ­proÂ­duced is necÂ­esÂ­sarÂ­ily an act of transÂ­laÂ­tion. Translating from this color space to that; from an adÂ­diÂ­tive color model of a screen to the subÂ­tracÂ­tive color model of ink and paÂ­per; apÂ­proxÂ­iÂ­matÂ­ing the color of a paÂ­per stock to be printed on.

This transÂ­latÂ­ing process is done usÂ­ing someÂ­thing called a Color Proï¬le. A Color Proï¬le is a set of rules for enÂ­surÂ­ing that an imÂ­age creÂ­ated with red, green, and blue light can be repliÂ­cated on off-white paÂ­per usÂ­ing cyan, maÂ­genta, yelÂ­low, orÂ­ange, and green inks. The curÂ­rent workÂ­ï¬‚ow of digÂ­iÂ­tal to print is so smooth, so ubiqÂ­uiÂ­tous and munÂ­dane, as to ocÂ­clude the masÂ­sive techÂ­noÂ­logÂ­iÂ­cal feat that it supÂ­ports it.

This feat was unÂ­derÂ­taken by a small group of techÂ­nolÂ­ogy comÂ­paÂ­nies I the early 90s, and they colÂ­labÂ­oÂ­rated to deÂ­ï¬ne a uniÂ­verÂ­sal stanÂ­dard of how this would work.

The International Color Consortium was formed in 1993 by eight inÂ­dusÂ­try venÂ­dors in orÂ­der to creÂ­ate an open, venÂ­dor-neuÂ­tral color manÂ­ageÂ­ment sysÂ­tem which would funcÂ­tion transÂ­parÂ­ently across all opÂ­erÂ­atÂ­ing sysÂ­tems and softÂ­ware packÂ­ages. . . . The eight foundÂ­ing memÂ­bers of the ICC were Adobe, Agfa, Apple, Kodak, Microsoft, Silicon Graphics, Sun Microsystems, and Taligent.

- Color Science History and the ICC Proï¬le Speciï¬cations, Elle Stone

The curÂ­rent, baseÂ­line proÂ­ï¬les built around RGB and CMYK came about with the rise of digÂ­iÂ­tal imÂ­age-makÂ­ing, which is the baÂ­sis of the the curÂ­rent world around us, a world built on and predÂ­iÂ­cated by imÂ­ages.

The domÂ­iÂ­nant transÂ­laÂ­tion is domÂ­iÂ­nant beÂ­cause it â€” to a large deÂ­gree â€” works. Creating color proÂ­ï¬le is reÂ­ally hard, mathy, phÂ­sysicsy stuff. Itâ€™s hard to do yourÂ­self. But CMYK/RGB cuts the corÂ­ners off the world to make it ï¬t into a gamut that can be hanÂ­dled. But by neÂ­cesÂ­sity itâ€™s a comÂ­proÂ­mise: what colÂ­ors are we not hanÂ­dling in orÂ­der to hanÂ­dle the maxÂ­iÂ­mum numÂ­ber of colÂ­ors? What parts of the color space get left beÂ­hind?

Many of these isÂ­sues give me the feelÂ­ing at times of reÂ­lucÂ­tant rather than open co-opÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion beÂ­tween some of the comÂ­paÂ­nies that creÂ­ated this stanÂ­dard. Having said that, there does seem enough inÂ­forÂ­maÂ­tion in the pubÂ­lic stanÂ­dard (when comÂ­bined with exÂ­amÂ­inÂ­ing availÂ­able exÂ­istÂ­ing proÂ­ï¬les) to efÂ­fecÂ­tively and acÂ­cuÂ­rately charÂ­acÂ­terÂ­ize color proÂ­ï¬les of deÂ­vices and color spaces. I could imagÂ­ine there beÂ­ing some poor reÂ­sults at times though, due to some looseÂ­ness in the spec.

â€” Whatâ€™s wrong with the ICC proÂ­ï¬le forÂ­mat anyÂ­way?, Graeme Gill

Its imÂ­porÂ­tant to unÂ­derÂ­stand this comÂ­proÂ­mise; unÂ­derÂ­stand how it works and what exÂ­change weâ€™re makÂ­ing in the process. What are we givÂ­ing up, and what are we getÂ­ting in reÂ­turn?

What are we leavÂ­ing on the table? For exÂ­amÂ­ple, phoÂ­togÂ­raÂ­phy (up unÂ­til the 80â€²s) calÂ­iÂ­brated for white peoÂ­ple. African Americans and other dark skinned peoÂ­ple phoÂ­tographed poorly. They were outÂ­side the color space. The story goes that school phoÂ­tos of inÂ­terÂ­raÂ­cial classÂ­rooms would have rows of perÂ­fectly exÂ­posed white kids, and voids where the black chilÂ­dren should have been (Adamn Broomberg). More than this, the stanÂ­dards only changed with inÂ­dusÂ­try presÂ­sure from chocoÂ­late and furÂ­niÂ­ture manÂ­uÂ­facÂ­turÂ­ers â€” a realm of capÂ­iÂ­tal where the browns and blacks matÂ­ter (Rosie Cima).

Film chemÂ­istry, photo lab proÂ­ceÂ­dures, video screen colour balÂ­ancÂ­ing pracÂ­tices, and digÂ­iÂ­tal camÂ­eras in genÂ­eral were origÂ­iÂ­nally deÂ­velÂ­oped with a global asÂ­sumpÂ­tion of â€˜Whiteness.â€™â€

â€” Looking at Shirley, the Ultimate Norm: Colour Balance, Image Technologies, and Cognitive Equity, Lorna Roth

With the creÂ­ation of the RGB color space, with the creÂ­ation of the ICC, we ceded the viÂ­sual world to suÂ­perÂ­masÂ­sive tech inÂ­terÂ­ests, much like weâ€™ve ceded our priÂ­vacy and perÂ­sonal data. In doÂ­ing so weâ€™ve inÂ­herÂ­ently made the creÂ­ation and disÂ­semÂ­iÂ­naÂ­tion of imÂ­ages into a tool for capÂ­iÂ­tal â€” one that supÂ­ports domÂ­iÂ­nant power strucÂ­tures.

How do we unÂ­derÂ­stand the imÂ­plicit, inÂ­visÂ­iÂ­ble, baked in asÂ­sumpÂ­tions of the soft proof? We can start by opÂ­erÂ­atÂ­ing outÂ­side the paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ters of the soft proof, recÂ­ogÂ­nize it as a tool to use or not use. The gap beÂ­tween the soft proof & the hard copy is meaÂ­sured in the gap beÂ­tween the tools used to plan & preÂ­pare verÂ­sus the tools used to proÂ­duce, and we can move in to this gap and inÂ­habit it. We can creÂ­ate work here, and in doÂ­ing so reÂ­claim some of the space that weâ€™ve given away.

The Risograph, for exÂ­amÂ­ple, has a toolÂ­chain for soft proofÂ­ing, but the maÂ­chineâ€” through its high speed & low cost â€” also opens up the posÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity of deÂ­signÂ­ing imÂ­ages through itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tive hard proofs; blendÂ­ing the techÂ­niques go the modÂ­ern digÂ­iÂ­tal print process with the clasÂ­siÂ­cal anaÂ­log ones.

The web is a strange medium — a blendÂ­ing of soft and hard spaces. A plasÂ­tique space, with plasÂ­tic proofs and plasÂ­tic copies. The same process of transÂ­laÂ­tion is at work â€” beÂ­tween the still & the inÂ­terÂ­acÂ­tive, ï¬‚owÂ­ing imÂ­age. This is why showÂ­ing comps & wireÂ­frames of webÂ­sites to clients can be so tricky: our culÂ­ture of imÂ­age cult and techÂ­noÂ­logÂ­iÂ­cal process can elide the critÂ­iÂ­cal difÂ­ferÂ­ences we sense as agents of these sysÂ­tems.

This is a call for a Marxism of imÂ­age makÂ­ing â€” to seize the means of proÂ­ducÂ­tion. To creÂ­ate radÂ­iÂ­cal imÂ­ages & tools that exÂ­ist in the corÂ­ners of the gamut and color spaces disÂ­carded by the soft proof. To unÂ­derÂ­stand that planÂ­ning is not doÂ­ing, and take conÂ­trol of our own viÂ­sual lanÂ­guages.

meta.title: How to Design While Developing
meta.description: Moving beÂ­yond the idea that the deÂ­signer and the deÂ­velÂ­oper on a web proÂ­ject are difÂ­ferÂ­ent peoÂ­ple, and that someÂ­how those are difÂ­ferÂ­ent things.

content:
For a long time, webÂ­sites got made with one perÂ­son deÂ­signÂ­ing how it should look and one perÂ­son deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ing the code that made it look that way.

A lot of times, this is still how things get done - one team makes staÂ­tic Photoshop comps, and hands them off to a team of deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ers who know stuff like whether React or Ember or Node or Ruby is the best thing. This can someÂ­times cause fricÂ­tion. The deÂ­signer exÂ­pects the webÂ­site to look exÂ­actly like the comp, the deÂ­velÂ­oper writes a bunch of cusÂ­tom CSS and HTML to ï¬t the deÂ­sign, and whoÂ­ever needs to make sure the whole thing is WCAAG comÂ­pliÂ­ant spends weeks hatÂ­ing both of them. When the next comp comes down the line, it all hapÂ­pens again. For a big site, this leads to deÂ­sign drift, and a hugely tanÂ­gled codeÂ­base thatâ€™s a nightÂ­mare to try and unÂ­tanÂ­gle.

This splitÂ­ting of sysÂ­tems is an arÂ­tiÂ­ï¬Â­cial one thatâ€™s susÂ­tained by orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tional asÂ­sumpÂ­tions: we need deÂ­signÂ­ers, and we need deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ers. The thing about Design though - capÂ­iÂ­tal D deÂ­sign - is that itâ€™s simÂ­ply a method of deÂ­cidÂ­ing on a strucÂ­ture to acÂ­comÂ­plish a purÂ­pose. The deÂ­sign tools and methÂ­ods one uses to acÂ­comÂ­plish good deÂ­sign is alÂ­ways in tune with the thing beÂ­ing made. A buildÂ­ing doesÂ­nâ€™t go from paintÂ­ing to conÂ­strucÂ­tion drawÂ­ings, nor does a car go from modÂ­elÂ­ing clay to raceÂ­track. The clay and the paint are very useÂ­ful steps to start the process of deÂ­sign. They help us to be creÂ­ative and loose and exÂ­plore new soÂ­luÂ­tions to the probÂ­lems at hand. This exÂ­ploratory work helps us to unÂ­derÂ­stand how a thing will feel in the world.

These iniÂ­tial drawÂ­ings and sketches get transÂ­lated into their ï¬Â­nal strucÂ­tures, and transÂ­laÂ­tion is a process that can enÂ­rich both what is beÂ­ing transÂ­lated to as well as what is beÂ­ing transÂ­lated from. Every preÂ­cise moÂ­ment may not align diÂ­rectly, since difÂ­ferÂ­ences in conÂ­text can have deep imÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tions for meanÂ­ing.

We turn our drawÂ­ings into obÂ­jects with all the conÂ­sidÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tions of the ï¬Â­nal maÂ­teÂ­riÂ­alÂ­ity preÂ­sent. We canâ€™t igÂ­nore the shape of the enÂ­gine or strucÂ­tural code reÂ­quireÂ­ments, alÂ­though our modÂ­els and paintÂ­ings cerÂ­tainly can. Design is proÂ­viÂ­sional unÂ­til the point at which it exÂ­ists in the world, and when talkÂ­ing about the web even this isÂ­nâ€™t any sort of endÂ­ing. A webÂ­site is its own sort of thing, with its own strucÂ­ture and reÂ­quireÂ­ments that need to be preÂ­sent and known throughÂ­out the enÂ­tire process of deÂ­sign.

A drawÂ­ing and a webÂ­site will never look the same. This is mostly beÂ­cause a webÂ­site isÂ­nâ€™t staÂ­tic. Because of this, what a webÂ­site looks like is just a small piece of what a webÂ­site is. A webÂ­site is what it enÂ­ables its users to acÂ­comÂ­plish, what its deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ers have to do to keep it staÂ­ble and movÂ­ing forÂ­ward.

The best way to meet our goals as peoÂ­ple who make good webÂ­sites is to foÂ­cus less on those drawÂ­ings right away. Instead we should think more about simÂ­plicÂ­ity and elÂ­eÂ­gance than the deÂ­tail oriÂ­ented perÂ­fecÂ­tion of a jpeg.

Donâ€™t get me wrong - the jpeg can be imÂ­porÂ­tant. It shows us how we think we can solve our probÂ­lems, a glimpse of how we want our webÂ­site to looks and feel, and the tone we want to comÂ­muÂ­niÂ­cate. Through all this it needs to have to room to change and breath as it comes to life and beÂ­come a real thing. Our drawÂ­ings should not be on the level of â€œwhat does this look likeâ€ but â€œwhat probÂ­lem does this solve and howâ€. At every step in the process we can work to make the real thing betÂ­ter, to solve new quesÂ­tions that arise as we move through the process of deÂ­signâ€Š/â€ŠdeÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ment — a process where there is no gap beÂ­tween those two ideas.

To deÂ­sign a webÂ­site is to deÂ­velop it - and as we deÂ­velop a webÂ­site we are conÂ­stantly makÂ­ing deÂ­sign deÂ­ciÂ­sions. A deÂ­signer canÂ­not abÂ­diÂ­cate their reÂ­sponÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity to deÂ­sign by sayÂ­ing â€œwell, my jpeg looked great.â€ A deÂ­velÂ­oper canÂ­not abÂ­diÂ­cate their reÂ­sponÂ­siÂ­bilÂ­ity to a codeÂ­base by sayÂ­ing â€œwell thatâ€™s what they wanted in the comp.â€

meta.title: Building a Client Library for ArcGIS
meta.description: Writing a wrapÂ­per client liÂ­brary to smooth out deÂ­sign weirdÂ­ness at the API level leads to plenty of deÂ­sign thinkÂ­ing on the way things should be.

content:
This year I built a JavaScript wrapÂ­per for Node and the Browser around the ArcGIS REST API to simÂ­plify workÂ­ing with that platÂ­form as a deÂ­velÂ­oper. This was as an exÂ­erÂ­cise in API deÂ­sign, as well as makÂ­ing a tool that I wanted to use but didÂ­nâ€™t exÂ­ist yet. The proÂ­ject is a bare-bones liÂ­brary to ease inÂ­terÂ­acÂ­tions with the ArcGIS REST API in JavaScript and Node apps.

Sometimes — and for sure in this case — an API can be rough, built over time, and not proÂ­vide the sort of logÂ­iÂ­cal modÂ­els that work well with speÂ­ciï¬c lanÂ­guage enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­ments. This was the case with the ArcGIS REST API that I was runÂ­ning in to. A lot of the deÂ­ciÂ­sions had been made over the course of years, and didÂ­nâ€™t transÂ­late very smoothly a lanÂ­guage as young as Node.js.

The ï¬rst step was to ï¬gÂ­ure out what probÂ­lems I wanted to solve. A lot of my work with Esri PDX has been about conÂ­tent hanÂ­dling, and so this is where I started. Reading all the doc to get a big picÂ­ture of whatâ€™s goÂ­ing on with the API, and talk to everyÂ­one whoâ€™s done work like this beÂ­fore to ï¬gÂ­ure out what probÂ­lems they needed to solve was the ï¬rst step. From there I felt I had enough conÂ­text and inÂ­forÂ­maÂ­tion to make the thing useÂ­ful for more peoÂ­ple than just me, and make sure that it was coÂ­herÂ­ent with the unÂ­derÂ­lyÂ­ing goals of the origÂ­iÂ­nal API.

This proÂ­ject works to simÂ­plify and unify the gap beÂ­tween the ArcGIS REST API and a conÂ­temÂ­poÂ­rary Node apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion. This liÂ­brary is a UI in the most baÂ­sic sense of the term â€” it proÂ­vides an inÂ­terÂ­face beÂ­tween the deÂ­velÂ­oper and the servers. That inÂ­terÂ­face needs to be well deÂ­signed and thoughtÂ­ful in orÂ­der to make the process as smooth, inÂ­tuÂ­itive, and pleaÂ­surÂ­able as posÂ­siÂ­ble.

One of the most imÂ­porÂ­tant parts of the proÂ­ject is to proÂ­vide deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ers with a way to acÂ­cess the ArcGIS platÂ­form withÂ­out needÂ­ing to arÂ­chiÂ­tect their enÂ­tire apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion around opinÂ­ionÂ­ated frameÂ­works (like Dojo, for exÂ­amÂ­ple). Though the liÂ­brary itÂ­self is writÂ­ten in ES6, itâ€™s disÂ­tribÂ­uted as plain, norÂ­mal ES5 — both as a node packÂ­age and a packÂ­aged bunÂ­dle. This means it works both in Node and the browser, and has very few opinÂ­ions on how it inÂ­teÂ­grates with the rest of your app.

Right now, the liÂ­brary wraps most of the baÂ­sic platÂ­form conÂ­tent manÂ­ageÂ­ment and inÂ­terÂ­acÂ­tions - getÂ­ting and editÂ­ing users, orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tions, and items. The Node ArcGIS Client Library is an open source proÂ­ject â€” so itâ€™s scope will inÂ­crease as the comÂ­muÂ­nity works to acÂ­comÂ­plish more goals and workÂ­ï¬‚ows.

Setting up the client

The ï¬rst step in usÂ­ing the liÂ­brary is iniÂ­tialÂ­izÂ­ing the client with your tarÂ­get porÂ­tal.

var ArcGIS = require('arcgis')
var arcgis = ArcGIS()

This sets up a deÂ­fault obÂ­ject for inÂ­terÂ­actÂ­ing with the API. This deÂ­fault is goÂ­ing to talk to ArcGIS Online as an anonyÂ­mous, unauÂ­thenÂ­tiÂ­cated user. One can auÂ­thenÂ­tiÂ­cate this client sesÂ­sion as a named user by passÂ­ing in a user toÂ­ken obÂ­tained from a sucÂ­cessÂ­ful OAuth loÂ­gin process.

var arcgis = Arcgis({
  token: namedUserToken
})

This isÂ­nâ€™t exÂ­cluÂ­sive to ArcGIS Online. The API for inÂ­terÂ­actÂ­ing with your orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tionâ€™s inÂ­stalÂ­laÂ­tion of Portal or Server is the same. Setting up the client sesÂ­sion with your inÂ­stance is done by specÂ­iÂ­fyÂ­ing your API doÂ­main.

var arcgis = Arcgis({
  domain: 'ago.my-server.com',
  token: namedUserToken
})

Beyond the iniÂ­tialÂ­izaÂ­tion of the client, the liÂ­brary is exÂ­cluÂ­sively async. All the funcÂ­tions reÂ­turn promises by deÂ­fault.

function log (m) {
  console.log(m)
}
function ohNo (err) {
  return new Error(err)
}
arcgis.request()
.then(log)
.catch(ohNo)

You can also pass in a node-style callÂ­back, if youâ€™d preÂ­fer.

function log (err, results) {
  if (err) {
    return new Error(err)
  } else {
    console.log(results)
  }
}
arcgis.request({}, log)

Both methÂ­ods work just as well, and use all the same busiÂ­ness logic. I like promises, but maybe you donâ€™t. This is one of the main reaÂ­sons the liÂ­brary does its best to avoid inÂ­ï¬‚ictÂ­ing my opinÂ­ions on your codeÂ­base.

Once we have an auÂ­thenÂ­tiÂ­cated sesÂ­sion, we can do all sorts of stuff â€” like ï¬gÂ­ure out who we are:

function hello (user) {
  console.log('Hello, ' + user.firstName)
}
arcgis.user('NikolasWise').then(hello)

We can get all of the items that user has in the platÂ­form:

function getContent (user) {
  return user.content()
}
function logContent (content) {
  console.log(content)
}
arcgis.user('NikolasWise')
.then(getContent)
.then(logContent)

Or a list of all the groups that a user is a memÂ­ber of.

function logGroups (item) {
  item.groups.forEach(function (group) {
    console.log(group.title)
  })
}
arcgis.user('NikolasWise').then(logGroups)

The liÂ­brary also can inÂ­terÂ­act with the userâ€™s orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tion, reÂ­turnÂ­ing inÂ­forÂ­maÂ­tion, memÂ­bers, or all the conÂ­tent asÂ­soÂ­ciÂ­ated with the orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tion.

function logOrg (org) {
  console.log(org)
}
arcgis.organization('esripdx').then(logOrg)

The orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tion call deÂ­faults to â€˜selfâ€™ â€” whatÂ­ever orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tion the curÂ­rent user is a memÂ­ber of.

function getMembers (org) {
  return org.members()
}
function log (members) {
  console.log(members)
}
arcgis.organization().then(getMembers).then(log)

Many of the conÂ­tent calls are abÂ­stracÂ­tions or helper methÂ­ods for longer, more comÂ­pliÂ­cated calls to the search endÂ­point.

function getContent (org) {
  return org.content()
}
function log (items) {
  console.log(items)
}
arcgis.organization().then(getContent).then(log)

In this way we are able to creÂ­ate a tranÂ­siÂ­tional layer beÂ­tween the API itÂ­self (a suÂ­per comÂ­pliÂ­cated call to the search endÂ­point) and what apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion deÂ­velÂ­opÂ­ers need (all my orÂ­gaÂ­niÂ­zaÂ­tionâ€™s conÂ­tent).

Working with conÂ­tent

Looking at maps as they exÂ­ist toÂ­day on the inÂ­terÂ­net, we have a pretty solid idea of what that means. It means they look like Google Maps. The Google Maps model is a good one, too! Itâ€™s a very efÂ­fecÂ­tive way to preÂ­sent what is esÂ­senÂ­tially a road map - a driÂ­vers atÂ­las for navÂ­iÂ­gatÂ­ing a city or a counÂ­try. Google Maps reÂ­places the AAA State Highway map reÂ­ally efÂ­fecÂ­tively, but perÂ­haps there are some weak links with how it apÂ­plies to other, less navÂ­iÂ­gaÂ­tion-oriÂ­ented maps.

There a large numÂ­ber of reÂ­ally beauÂ­tiÂ­ful maps that exÂ­ist only on paÂ­per, and a large numÂ­ber of reÂ­ally ugly maps that exÂ­ist on screens. How can we start to think about maps in a way that bridges this gap? Is there a way we can apÂ­proach these other, not-a-roadmap-map maps more efÂ­fecÂ­tively to make them as good as their paÂ­per-bound cousins?

To apÂ­proach this quesÂ­tion from an anÂ­gle, itâ€™s worth takÂ­ing a moÂ­ment to think about what a map is. The map is a miniaÂ­ture that pivÂ­ots around the body to repÂ­reÂ­sent the giÂ­ganÂ­tic enorÂ­mity of the physÂ­iÂ­cal world. The map shrinks the world down to a place it can be held in the hands and enÂ­tirely seen with the eye. The map conÂ­nects the vastÂ­ness of reÂ­alÂ­ity to the body in way that can be hanÂ­dled - both physÂ­iÂ­cally and menÂ­tally.

This creÂ­ates tenÂ­sion with maps on the screen - esÂ­peÂ­cially the inÂ­terÂ­net. The screen can not be touched, and the inÂ­terÂ­net can not be reÂ­lated to the body. Phones and tablets mitÂ­iÂ­gate this by bringÂ­ing the screen closer, and movÂ­ing to the size of the hand, but the core difÂ­ï¬Â­culty reÂ­mains — if a map exÂ­ists to scale down the enorÂ­mity of the world to the size of the body, the inÂ­terÂ­net itÂ­self has no boundÂ­aries or edges, and way to reÂ­late the screen to the body.

Why is this conÂ­necÂ­tion beÂ­tween world and body imÂ­porÂ­tant? The map proÂ­vides conÂ­text for unÂ­derÂ­standÂ­ing world-scale sysÂ­tems and landÂ­scape-scale conÂ­cepts in a huÂ­man-scale obÂ­ject. The map is a tyÂ­polÂ­ogy of comÂ­muÂ­niÂ­caÂ­tion that sits half way beÂ­tween the book and the viÂ­sual art obÂ­ject. Both the book and the paintÂ­ing — or the print — are techÂ­niques that are used to proÂ­vide acÂ­cess to conÂ­cepts and ideas beÂ­yond the scale of a sinÂ­gle inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual. The book can conÂ­tain cenÂ­turies of inÂ­telÂ­lecÂ­tual thought, the paintÂ­ing can exÂ­pose feelÂ­ings and emoÂ­tions that touch any numÂ­ber of peoÂ­ple. If the map exÂ­ists beÂ­tween these two mode of comÂ­muÂ­niÂ­caÂ­tion, that means that itâ€™s goal is to use a volÂ­ume of thought, of data, of meaÂ­sureÂ­ments to exÂ­pose a broad, unÂ­derÂ­lyÂ­ing conÂ­cept. This can be an enÂ­viÂ­ronÂ­menÂ­tal truth (or the supÂ­poÂ­siÂ­tion of one) or a soÂ­ciÂ­etal inÂ­sight.

The map does this through a very speÂ­ciï¬c set of viÂ­sual deÂ­sign tools with forÂ­mal qualÂ­iÂ­ties that lend themÂ­selves to the probÂ­lem at hand. These forÂ­malÂ­iÂ­ties are partly deÂ­ï¬ned and strucÂ­tured by the techÂ­noloÂ­gies beÂ­hind the proÂ­ducÂ­tion and disÂ­triÂ­bÂ­uÂ­tion of the map.

The ï¬rst maps where hand drawn, and corÂ­reÂ­spondÂ­ingly have atÂ­tribÂ­utes of other hand-made viÂ­sual works. With the adÂ­vent of printÂ­ing, maps started to be carved into wood, and duÂ­pliÂ­cated. After wood, they came to etchÂ­ing, and afÂ­ter that lithÂ­oÂ­gÂ­raÂ­phy. In each of the print techÂ­niques, cerÂ­tain marks are faÂ­vored and made posÂ­siÂ­ble through the medium of the maÂ­trix itÂ­self. Shared in all the print techÂ­niques, howÂ­ever, is the conÂ­cept of plates — inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual drawn layÂ­ers for difÂ­ferÂ­ent colÂ­ors. Equating inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual plates to inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual colÂ­ors to inÂ­diÂ­vidÂ­ual tyÂ­poÂ­logÂ­iÂ­cal conÂ­cepts beÂ­ing shown on the map is a big reaÂ­son why printed maps are so good.

The careÂ­ful and deÂ­libÂ­erÂ­ate apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion of the maps forÂ­mal charÂ­acÂ­terÂ­isÂ­tics to diÂ­rectly adÂ­dress the ideas and conÂ­cepts to be comÂ­muÂ­niÂ­cated, the adÂ­dress the use of the map is what makes a map good.

On the inÂ­terÂ­net, we make maps difÂ­ferÂ­ently. GIS data sets mean that maps can be made through mathÂ­eÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cal and anÂ­aÂ­lytic tools — comÂ­parÂ­ing sets of data, and creÂ­atÂ­ing new sets of data to anÂ­swer quesÂ­tions. A roÂ­bust and open set of pubÂ­lic data means that there are map makÂ­ing tools which proÂ­vide ways to style and comÂ­bine exÂ­istÂ­ing conÂ­tent.

These techÂ­niques utiÂ­lize a relÂ­aÂ­tively staÂ­tic map that purÂ­ports to useÂ­fully deÂ­scribe the enÂ­tire geÂ­ogÂ­raÂ­phy of the planet. All of the maps made are inÂ­tended to sit within larger apÂ­pliÂ­caÂ­tion, itÂ­self deÂ­signed to solve a probÂ­lem.

Most of the time, these maps fail to proÂ­vide meanÂ­ingÂ­ful conÂ­necÂ­tion to the conÂ­cepts proÂ­vided - they lose the esÂ­senÂ­tial asÂ­pect of the map that join world-to-huÂ­man scales, inÂ­stead opÂ­erÂ­atÂ­ing at the world-to-world level. The endÂ­less map of the inÂ­terÂ­net is itÂ­self inÂ­comÂ­preÂ­henÂ­siÂ­ble to the body. The maps of the inÂ­terÂ­net are siÂ­mulÂ­taÂ­neÂ­ously too broad and too simÂ­ple, proÂ­vidÂ­ing too much and too litÂ­tle. The probÂ­lem the map is preÂ­sentÂ­ing itÂ­self as a soÂ­luÂ­tion too is usuÂ­ally far too muddy, and the reÂ­sultÂ­ing lack of clarÂ­ity of purÂ­pose leads to a map with itÂ­self a lack of clarÂ­ity.

Looking to the main purÂ­pose of the map â€” simÂ­plicÂ­ity, clarÂ­ity, and the miniaÂ­turÂ­izaÂ­tion of the world to pivot around the huÂ­man hand â€” while usÂ­ing the forÂ­mal viÂ­sual tools and deÂ­sign lessons of the preÂ­viÂ­ous sevÂ­eral cenÂ­turies of paÂ­per maps — the balÂ­ance of simÂ­pliÂ­ï¬Â­caÂ­tion and exÂ­agÂ­gerÂ­aÂ­tion, clear conÂ­cepÂ­tual sepÂ­aÂ­raÂ­tions, and emÂ­bracÂ­ing the limÂ­iÂ­taÂ­tions of the obÂ­ject to proÂ­vide foÂ­cus.

In the anaÂ­log world we talk about the three funÂ­daÂ­menÂ­tal comÂ­poÂ­nents of print.
